column2:
The trade route gives the following effects:
$MODIFIER$

Trade posts built in trade route provinces increase the modifier for all provinces. If some trade route provinces are blocked (by siege or occupation), other trade route provinces temporarily get a higher bonus as trade is redirected.
column3:
La route de la soie procure les effets suivants :
$MODIFICATEURS$

Les comptoirs commerciaux présents dans des provinces où passe la route de la soie augmentent le modificateur de toutes les provinces. Si certaines provinces de la route de la soie sont bloquées (par un siège ou une occupation), d'autres provinces de la route de la soie reçoivent temporairement un bonus plus élevé en raison de la redirection des activités commerciales.
column4:
Die Seidenstraße erzeugt folgende Effekte:
$MODIFIER$

In Seidenstraßenprovinzen gebaute Handelsposten erhöhen den Modifikator aller Provinzen. Wenn einige Provinzen der Seidenstraße blockiert sind (besetzt sind oder belagert werden), erhalten andere Seidenstraßenprovinzen vorübergehend einen höheren Bonus, da der Handel umgeleitet wird.
column6:
La Ruta de la seda da los siguientes efectos:
$MODIFIER$

Puestos comerciales en las provincias de la Ruta de la seda aumentan el modificador para todas las provincias. Si algunas provincias de la Ruta de la seda están bloqueadas (por asedio u ocupación), otras provincias de la Ruta de la seda obtendrán una mayor bonificación temporal al redirigirse el comercio.

column2: Royal Road

The Royal Road was a road running through the Achaemenid Empire from Persepolis to Sardis. It was essential in maintaining communication across the Achaemenid Empire as it reduced courier travel time from 90 days to a mere 9 days. All along the Royal Road there were stations so the couriers could get fresh horses and traders could stay for the night./nThe origins of the Royal Road are not very well known. It is suggested that many parts of the road were built by the Assyrians, as the road did not follow the easiest or shortest route. It is known however, that Darius I unified the road and constructed all of the waystations. The Achaemenid Empire continued using the road as a post road for the remainder of its existence. After the Achaemenid Empire fell to Alexander's sword, the Royal Road fell into decay as the Middle East became more fractured due to the Diadochi Wars. The quality of the road was so high it continued to be used into Roman times.

A small dirt road. While expense and time consuming to dig, this dirt road is much better than no road at all. The road will entice more traders to go through this province and it will speed up armies using the road.
A paved road is a great improvement over the old dirt road. The pavement means that the road can take the stress from heavy traffic, both from armies as well as traders.
At this point the paved road can not handle the traffic anymore. By increasing the width of the road, more carts can use it at the same time.

The Royal Road was a road running through the Middle East from Persepolis to Sardis. It greatly increased the speed of communication by establishing more than 100 waystations across the road. These waystations contained fresh horses so couriers could travel at full speed. This way, a journey of 90 days on foot could be reduced to just 9 on horseback.

A small guard post would greatly increase security of the trade post while not costing too much. While the guard post is insufficiently manned to ward off enemy armies, they can hold their own against bandits.
By establishing patrols, we can track down and defeat bandits who are lurking far outside of the trade post.
Establising a small garrison will protect the trade post from enemy foraging parties. Traders will feel safe inside the trade post.
By building a wall around the trade post, it will be able to fend off large armies... for a while.
Build an inn to let traders rest, drink and exchange rumors.
A Caravanserai is a resting stop with a large square outside. Traders can rest and store their goods here. The square can also function as a marketplace.
